title: Grain to glass: Craft distilleries welcome visitors for tastings, tours
text:
CLOSE

With more than 1,500 distilleries around the nation, it’s easier than ever to find a local drink. Fueled by the farm-to-table food movement, craft makers are touting their grain-to-glass spirits.

Nearly all welcome visitors for tours and tastings, says Drew Beard, assistant editor for Drinkhacker.com, a site with thousands of reviews.

“People want an experience in their meals, and an experience in their beverages,” reasons Beard, who shares some of his favorite tasting rooms with USA TODAY.

Copper Fox Distillery, Sperryville and Williamsburg, Virginia

Copper Fox Distillery's new location in Williamsburg, Virginia, occupies a former motel. (Photo: Copper Fox Distillery)

With a distilling history older than the nation, Virginia is no stranger to fermentation. This long-time maker produces whiskey, rye, bourbon and gin, some made with apple, cherry and even sassafras wood.

The original location near Shenandoah National Park is based in a former apple warehouse, and the newest in Williamsburg is in a repurposed motor lodge. Both offer tastings and cocktails.

More information: copperfoxdistillery.com

Westward Whiskey, Portland, Oregon

You can taste Westward Whiskey's wares at their tasting room at Portland International Airport. Be careful choosing which product you buy, though: the TSA bans liquors over 70% alcohol (140 proof) from checked and carry-on luggage. (Photo: Westward Whiskey,)

Even if you’re stuck at Porland’s airport, you can still sample whiskeys since this innovative distillery has a tasting room in Concourse C and a tasting kiosk in Concourse D.

But if you can make it to the city, check out the 3,000-gallon still – which the company calls the largest west of the Mississippi. Wherever you go, make sure to try their Westward American Single Malt, Beard says.

More information: westwardwhiskey.com

FEW Spirits, Evanston, Illinois

The distillery's name is a nod to Frances Elizabeth Willard, longtime president of the Women’s Christian Temperance Union, an anti-drinking group. (Photo: @Apartment_Bartender)

More than a century ago, the National Women’s Christian Temperance Union led the fight for Prohibition from its base in the Chicago suburb of Evanston. Now the city’s home to FEW, named for Frances Elizabeth Willard, long-term president of the anti-drinking group.

It uses surprising techniques like making rye whiskey with French wine yeast or adding an Earl Grey tea flavor to its gin, Beard says. The unassuming distillery, reached off a back alley, also serves cocktails and welcomes drop-in tastings.

More information: fewspirits.com

Garrison Brothers, Hye, Texas

Garrison Brothers, whose tasting room is located in the Texas Hill Country, produced the first legal bourbon in the Lonestar State. (Photo: Julia Keim/Garrison Brothers)

With a location in the scenic Hill Country, this ranch-based distillery take visitors around the property on a Jeep-drawn trailer. Not only is the scenery memorable, but so is the taste of the first legal bourbon produced in Texas, Beard says.

More information: garrisonbros.com

Nelson’s Green Brier, Nashville

Nelson's Green Brier Distillery, located in Nashville was one of the country's premier spirit purveyors before Prohibition. (Photo: Courtesy of Nelson's Green Brier Distillery)

Like many spirits makers, this Tennessee company claims deep family ties. “In the craft distilling world, everyone’s joking they’re recreating their great, great, grandpappy’s recipe, but they’re one of the few that did,” Beard says.

Before Prohibition, the company was one of the country’s premier distilleries. Now it’s quickly finding a following again.

More information: greenbrierdistillery.com

McClintock Distilling, Frederick, Maryland

McClintock Distilling, located about an hour north of Washington in Frederick, Maryland, houses its tasting room in a century-old creekside garage. (Photo: McClintock Distilling)

Started in 2017, this young distillery shows where the industry’s heading. It’s one of the few certified as organic and uses non-GMO, pesticide-free heirloom grains. Already it has won awards for its gin and whiskey. “They’re clearly doing something right,” Beard says.

The setting in a creekside 100-year-old garage is memorable, as are the signature cocktails, which use ingredients like their Blood Orange Saffron Cordial.

More information: mcclintockdistilling.com

Charbay Distillery, Ukiah, California

Northern California's Charbay Distillery has been brewing for 13 generations. (Photo: Charbay Distillery)

This 13th-generation distiller started the current operation in 1983, making it a pioneer in the craft movement. “They’ve been doing this longer than almost anyone,” Beard says.

The maker’s best known for its natural, fruit-flavored vodkas and R5 whiskey, distilled from an IPA beer. Although located in Northern California’s Mendocino County, you can also taste the products at the family’s Napa Valley winery.

More information: charbay.com

Wilderness Trail, Danville, Kentucky

Kentucky's Wilderness Trail Distillery was founded by two former punk-rock bandmates. (Photo: Wilderness Trail)

It’s not easy to get noticed in the middle of Kentucky bourbon country, but this distillery has been turning heads.

The owners, who met in a rock and roll band, spent 20 years working as industry consultants before they started distilling in 2013. “They really hit the crafts spirits world with a splash,” Beard says.

More information: wildernesstraildistillery.com

One Eight Distilling, Washington, D.C.

One Eight is the first whiskey distillery in the nation’s capital since Prohibition. (Photo: Rey Lopez/One Eight Distilling)

This first whiskey distillery in the nation’s capital since Prohibition, this operation not only makes award-winning spirits, but is also a hip place for a drink, Beard says. “They do lots of fun cocktails with all the stuff they make in house.”

With a location in the upand-coming Ivy City area, it’s a great place to spend an evening. “They’ve blown out the wall and put in a big window. You can still see their brand new shiny column.”

More information: oneeightdistilling.com

Westland Distillery, Seattle

Visitors come to Westland Cantilever Room in Seattle for tours, tastings, seasonal cocktails and small-plate snacks. (Photo: Courtesy of Westland Distillery)

While the focus is single-malt, this distillery puts a distinctly Pacific Northwest spin on its whiskeys, using locally harvested peat and even barrels made from a regional oak.

“That’s about as terroir as it gets,” Beard says. “It’s super innovative, a phenomenal little distillery.”

Visitors come for tours, tastings, seasonal cocktails and small plate snacks.

More information:westlanddistillery.com
